Title: $x \otimes y - y \otimes x \neq 0$ in $I \otimes_{R} I$
Content:
Let $R = k[x,y]$ , $I = (x,y)$ , $k$ is a field. I want to prove that : 1) $x \otimes y - y \otimes x 
eq 0 $ in  $I \otimes_{R} I$ 2) $x \otimes y - y \otimes x $ is a torsion element My thoughts: to prove that $x \otimes y - y \otimes x 
eq 0 $ in  $I \otimes_{R} I$ probably I should find a bilinear map $$\phi : I 	imes I 	o R$$ such that $\phi(x,y) 
eq \phi (y,x)$ , but which one?
AcceptedAnswer:
Assume that $k$ is a commutative ring, put $t:=x\otimes y-y\otimes x$, and identify $k$ to $R/I$. 1) Using the $R$-bilinear map 
$$
I\times I\to k,\qquad(f,g)\mapsto
\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(0,0)\ 
\frac{\partial g}{\partial y}(0,0),
$$ 
it is easy to see that $t$ is nonzero. 2) We have $xyt=0$.
